video.title: HTML and CSS Tutorial - Create a Website for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the basics of HTML and CSS in this complete tutorial. You will create a band website project using HTML and learn how to apply modern design in order to style the site using CSS.

🔗CSS Crash Course: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1xBCi5SOjw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

⌨️ (00:00) Your first webpage
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20HTML/Lesson%201
⌨️ (4:18) Basic HTML elements
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20HTML/Lesson%202

⌨️ (14:20) Advanced HTML elements
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20HTML/Lesson%203
⌨️ (27:22) Links and elements
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20HTML/Lesson%204
⌨️ (42:19) CSS part 1
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20CSS/Lesson%201
⌨️ (1:13:35) CSS part 2
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20CSS/Lesson%202
⌨️ (1:36:09) CSS part 3
  💻 Code: https://github.com/WebDevSimplified/Introduction-to-Web-Development/tree/master/Introduction%20to%20CSS/Lesson%203


Tutorial created by Web Dev Simplified. Check out their channel for more great content: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCFbNIlppjAuEX4znoulh0Cw

Twitter: https://twitter.com/DevSimplified

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Web Dev Simplified
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for featuring my HTML and CSS tutorial Free Code Camp! If anyone has any questions let me know, because I would love to help out anyway I can.

Also, if you enjoyed this video please checkout my channel for more web development related tutorials.

topLevelComment.author: Lawrence Osh
topLevelComment.text:
The HTML mark-up is really frustrating, I'm here to learn HTML5 syntax, I'm not a beginner.
You are jumping around adding new tags, where you are supposed to add ahref, link, class, ID you left them out and come back later. In the beginning, you did not add div>container that wrap content on each page.
The mock-up shouldn't have an inline style and  can be easily adjusted in CSS, eg hr, &9658; and others. You could use a border, margin, padding,  img> width & height

Kudos though

replies.author: Nikola
replies.text: @Shubham Karn.  @Shubham Karn.  Then you path may be wrong. If you have a folder named CSS and style.css within it then in index.html your path should be "css/style.css". When you put the size in style.css file remove the one from index.html. If you don't remove it then it will always show the one from index.html.

topLevelComment.author: Csl
topLevelComment.text:
Update: it was as expected:  A typo in the code.

ASSITANCE PLEASE.  Issue area @: 1:35:06.  I've doubled and tripled check and some more.  All my codes are exactly the same, from the css to the htlm.  However, I'm not getting the same exact results.  Every things is pretty much similar except:
1. My Arena column is shifted to my City column creating a continuous string of text (only separated by a single space).
2. My "buy tickets" buttons are not equally lined up (vertically).  Aside from the 2nd and 3rd row, the rest all starts at a random spot, In close proximity but still not aligned.

I'm running this on Chrome.

Any body else has this issue?  Or if you had this issue, how would you code to correct it? (aside from me possibly just incorrectly copying the coding somewhere, which again I checked multiple times).

replies.author: Csl
replies.text:
I had an issue with CSS at first too, my codes on my css file were not linking to my html file to make the necessary changes.  After some more thorough review, I noticed I created the CCS file in my Image folder.  I deleted it, and recreated another file in the same exact folder my html files are.  Maybe you're experiencing the same thing.

Also don't forget to add <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"/> to the html.

topLevelComment.author: Marlon BL Herry
topLevelComment.text: I also saw CSS Grid and Flex Box being used as layout options - how does this tie into what you shared?

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Grid and Flexbox are both amazingly useful ways to layout a website. It really depends on the content, as to which layout method you choose, but Flexbox is applicable to almost any site. I have videos on both Grid and Flexbox that you can checkout here. https://youtu.be/fYq5PXgSsbE, and here https://youtu.be/9zBsdzdE4sM.

topLevelComment.author: Marlon BL Herry
topLevelComment.text: Why did you use type="button" on the index page and role="button" on the store page?

replies.author: Marlon BL Herry
replies.text: Thanks for the clarification.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Both type and role are valid attributes on the button element. I should be setting type for most of the buttons since the role of button defaults to button but the type defaults to submit and we should set that to button in our case. Overall this is not super important though since it will still work either way. It can just help accessibility for screen readers.

topLevelComment.author: BJ
topLevelComment.text: Great video.  Do adding a class to the header or nav make styling things easier? I'm trying to understand when do you know when to add a class or div to things.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text:
@BJ No problem. Sorry it took me so long. I don't get notifications for this video since it isn't on my channel, so I sometimes fall behind on replying. Divs are really useful for when you need to layout and style specific sections of content on your site. They should be used when there is no other HTML element such as header or footer that makes sense in that scenario.

Also, I personally feel that classes should be used in most scenarios for styling different HTML elements. Here is my Learn CSS in 20 Minutes video. I go into a bit more depth on using classes vs ids vs elements for selecting elements. Hopefully it helps explain things better than I can in this comment. https://youtu.be/1PnVor36_40

replies.author: BJ
replies.text: @Web Dev Simplified Thank you so much for responding. Im getting used to styling and I see alot of people that use a div and for almost everything.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: It makes it easier to style since your styles are no longer dependent on the actual HTML. If you wanted to add another header to a different page you could style it differently by just using a different class instead of having to override the other header styles.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: If you are talking about how I indent and un-indent my code it is just from highlighting the code and using tab to indent and shift+tab to un-indent. As long as you highlight more than one line it will indent or un-indent all the lines at once.

topLevelComment.text: For the tours of the band ,why didn't you use p tag

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Sorry for the late reply. I generally only use p tags for large paragraph style text content like the about section. This is because the p tag adds spacing around the text which I don't really want or need when adding short sections of text to the screen.

topLevelComment.author: Ryan Blais
topLevelComment.text: I can't seem to get the images to load. I put them in a folder called "images" inside my project folder, tried both the relative and absolute paths, and changed the backslashes "\" to forward slashes "/", but no success. Has anyone else had this problem?

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: @Ryan Blais you're welcome. Keep up the hard work.

replies.author: Ryan Blais
replies.text: Thanks @Web Dev Simplified, the images appeared as soon as I got rid of the "%20". I'm pretty new to web development, as I'm sure is obvious.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: @Ryan Blais the path to the image must be local to the index.html file. You should use 'images/Spotify Logo.png' unless the %20 is actually in the name of the file. In thay case use 'images/Spotify%20Logo.png' you don't need to include the folder that the html file is inside of.

replies.author: Ryan Blais
replies.text: Thanks for replying so fast. I used "Feigned_Indignants\images\Spotify%20Logo.png", where "Feigned_Indignants" is the name of the project folder. "index.html" is also in this folder, next to the images folder. I've also tried using forward slashes instead of the default backslashes.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Does your src path look like this 'images/image_name.png'? In my example my folder is Images with a capital I, so you may accidentally be using a capital I instead of a lowercase i.

topLevelComment.author: Mohammed Fachihul Alam
topLevelComment.text: What is the future o web design or development as Wordpress,Wix etc help to build website without knowing nothing about web design or development?PLs comment.

replies.author: Renaissance Man
replies.text:
I think that anyone who wants to professionally mak websites should know languages ​​such as JS, HTML, CSS but also be able to use systems such as wordpress or prestashop. Wordpress is also good for beginners and advanced web designers. I made my first video dedicated to wordpress for beginners.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L07jOK-0JYY&t=4s

replies.author: eniluck
replies.text: p.s. Roadmap to becoming a web developer in 2018 https://github.com/kamranahmedse/developer-roadmap

replies.author: eniluck
replies.text: Hi everyone. Let me share with you simple roadmap to become react developer. https://github.com/adam-golab/react-developer-roadmap

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: You will need to understand HTML, CSS, and JS at a strong level. You will then want to move onto learning about frontend frameworks such as React, or Angular. You will also need to have a strong understanding of Ajax, and knowing how to build a single page application would be useful but not required. You will also want to learn jQuery since it is used in many older systems, as well as bundlers like Webpack which are used in newer systems.
